content:
29, 2014
												Tropico 4, for lack of a better definition, is kind of like SimCity. But where SimCity stands as placing you as the mayor of a common, modern American city, Tropico puts you in the position of "El Presidente", the leader of a small Caribbean island nation at the height of the Cold War.Tropico 4 is a delightful game, and carries a number of excellent qualities. It exhibits a long, engaging campaign and offers moderate replay value for fans of city-building simulations. However, the true shine to Tropico is the tongue-in-cheek humor that underlies all gameplay and all story elements. The game has a relatively realistic basis to itself, but doesn't hesitate to recognize itself as what it essentially is - a Caribbean Dictator SimCity. And it does it wonderfully. Not only does the game make a couple of cheeky references, but it takes the mickey out of nearly everything within itself and keeps the mood lighthearted.In terms of gameplay, Tropico 4 maintains a solid city-building mechanic, but tacks on the added difficulty of managing and keeping the numerous factions and foreign countries in and around your island happy. There are the profit-obsessed Capitalists, the overzealous Communists, the hippy-heavy Environmentalists, and even skinhead Nationalists. Paired with the United States and the USSR breathing down your neck, it makes for interesting and suprisingly difficult gameplay. However, you will be rewarded graciously for dealing with each of the factions and nations as you grow your legacy as "El Presidente".I would recommend this game to most people, but this is a DEFINITE BUY for fans of city-builders.Also - to all you soon-to-be Presidentes, heres a few helpful tips:1. Set up your economy first. Always.2. Clinics and Churches are more necessary than you may think.3. I learned this late in my play sessions: Media is suprisingly helpful. You'd be suprised what a single newspaper can do.4. You DON'T need the DLC to play and have fun.5. In Vanilla Tropico 4 - power is for ♥♥♥♥♥es. Only make power plants if you are rich or really need them.6. In Modern Times Tropico 4 - power is for pros. Power is... well, power.7. Industry will always make you more money than agriculture.8. Agriculture is always more stable than industry.9. Remember to turn off Open Doors when you have enough people. This will eventually come to you in time.10. Don't be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Social Security is the best thing you can have if you know what you're doing.Have fun, Presidente!

content:
15, 2013
												There's an easy way to recommend this game: did you like Tropico 3? If yes, you'll dig this, if not, pass. This game's called Tropico 4 but it's nominally an expansion pack to Tropico 3, though a large one at that. Tropico is a nation-building game in the vein of the Anno series, though not nearly as in-depth and with a sense of humor. It features a few new buildings and edicts and some new mechanics, as well as an entirely new campaign. A few of the added structures make things a little easier- like the salt mine, a mine that never runs out, and the chemical plant, a factory that requires no input. The mechanic improvements serve to streamline the gameplay and the added buildings are interesting. The campaign is quite good and about 40 hours long, a decent amount of play can be had. There is of course a sandbox mode if all you wish to build is an island. I very much recommend this game if you enjoy city or nation building games.

content:
, 2014
												I've been a huge fan of Tropico since the 1st game. So much in fact, I rebought the 3rd game on steam just for digital purposes even though it's already installed with a disc. The series is fantastic, about operating your little island republic in quite literally any way you see fit. There are options galore, from being a totalitarian dictator to gracious president, a religious zealot to intellectual know-it-all, and more with factions to go along with them that will generally respect you for your actions towards that.That said, I'm only recommending this game because it's just easier to get this than Tropico 3 and it's expansion. If you already own tropico 3 and it's absolute power expansion, there really isn't much here. What you do get is some new voice-acted characters and storylines, which are nifty throughout the campaign and during side missions you get during your sandbox games, but as far as down-to-the-core gameplay goes you won't find any differences other than a couple new structures and a new voice actor for El Presidente's avatar.Regardless of the fact it is so similar to it's predecessor though, the tropico franchise is still unbelievably good as a sim and strategy game with a great sense of humor, and it really shows in this game where the humor factor goes up quite a bit due to that one major addition of the voiced characters. It's not simcity, it's not banished, and it sure as hell isn't Men of War or Company of Heroes, but if you want something that does a really good job of managing to fall somewhere right in the middle of all of those games, Tropico has you covered.And the 5th game is coming out next week, so here's to hoping it's godlike!

												Tropico is fun.  I grew up playing Sim City 2000 in the computer lab during my lunch break at school.  So these sort of city sims are fun to me.  I have to say that this game is really good.  There is a lot to master, but you can still succeed even if you don't master some of the basic struggles like poverty.  There are just a lot of different ways to go about running your society.  The game has a good sense of humor too.  I think even the economics are on point, to a degree.  Its well done.  My only complaint is that the graphics tend to be a bit disappointing in this game.

content:
16, 2014
												For the most part Tropico 4 is one of the first management games I've played in a while. I had a pretty massive gap with the my last really intense period of playing games from this genre involving Rollercoaster Tycoon and Theme Hospital, man those were some great games, then in the last few years I flirted with Football Manager before getting Cities in Motion and Tropico 4. What really drew me into Tropico 4 though is the theme and world that it built. While doing such world building isn't unique in management games, the world that Tropico 4 had built was. I was just really intrigued by the fact that you could attempt to embody some of the worst dictators in human history like Francois Duvalier or become a revolutionary like Fidel Castro or really be anything in between. I don't doubt that the reason behind this draw I felt to the game was my love for history and politics, so I'm pretty sure that anyone who has similar leanings is going to be drawn into the game much the same way I was.Tropico 4 isn't a game for everyone though. Hell, this entire genre isn't for everyone. At the end of the day the entire management genre is just spread sheet management and its your affinity with the world and theme the developers work on that is the reason you actually engage with it. All I can say for certain is that I really like the game, I enjoyed the use of real dictators, the work that was put into the music and art in the game and the fact that game as a whole doesn't take itself serious with all the characters in the game and its campaign being caricature of various historical figure. But I can definitely see that anyone who has no political or historical interests just won't find this game interesting at all and would lean towards another management game based on their interests.If you want to read a longer review of the game you can check it out on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/08/tropico-4.html.

content:
er 27, 2013
												I suck at this game.  So let's just get that out of the way, I'm TERRIBLE at this game.  But I love it, it's a blast.  Whether I'm dropping a condo onto a shanty town or I'm hiking the prices of medical care through the roof, life as a dictator is sweet.There are a ton of missions, each with altering goals but the same game play.  You'll have to please your people (Or don't, if you don't want to win and just think it's fun to play that way.  No harm no foul) if you want to stay in office long term.   It's a great game in a similar style as the city simulations, but with a ton of great humor mixed in.  I found myself regularly grinning and laughing at things I'd hear them say on the radio or to my dictator.

content:
ber 27, 2016
Product received for free
												Gameplay, Tropico 4 doesn't delve too far from the generic mechanics of a city building simulation genre. You manage your city/nation's economy, monitor the population, provide housing, food, services and employment, and construct buildings for some of their other needs such as healthcare and spirituality. The definitive characteristic of this one's you'll be tasked to focus on one island and only one island at a time (unlike in Anno where you can build on other nearby islands, here, other islands are almost non-existent). There's also balance on this one in terms of freedom on how you want to run your island. You have options on where to run your economy, be it Tourism or other forms of industry chains.Another strong selling point of this game's the dialogue, the humor is strong in this one. I hope I can also befriend someone from the Middle East who promises me a camel but sends me 30,000 USD on my way instead. Something his wives found while cleaning the couch.Visuals, score and other things, nothing really stands out here.So, yeah. I'd give this one a commend. Buy the DLC's too, if you can. I heard they make the game a little more rounded with options.Camels/10 will be a dictator again.

content:
er 23, 2016
												Vote El Presidente... Or else!Tropico is one of those games that make you appreciate the fact that smaller companies create so good games!Well,the task in this game is quite simple, rule your island as the Dictator, El Presidente, keep the political relations with the other nations to a good level, provide food, work, housing and other important needs for your fellow followers, listen to some of your(at some points) terribly annoying advisors! And last, but not least- Lead TROPICO to the Glory.Alright, this might not sound particularly interesting for many of you, I assume... sounds like yet another boring strategy game, right? Well... actually no. There is so much more to it than meets the eye, hidden in the small details that make this game unique:-The set and atmosphere: You are on a tropical island, Earth's paradise, never before seen beauty. The perfect place to become a dictator! The islands are made so beautifully, it really sets you in the relaxing mood of the tropical culture, so to speak. It is just beautiful to look at, from any angle. The palm trees, the small animals, the buildings(some of which are hilarious), the cars(honestly, I love the design of the cars.. like come on.. who wouldnt drive a car like that in real life? I certainly would!!), and all other small details make up for a really sweet game.-The soundtrack: Now, as I said before, the atmosphere is just amazing. But hold on there, buddy!! It gets even better when the music starts playing. You felt like you are on the island before the music started? Ha, just wait till the music starts, you don't feel like...YOU ARE on the island, right there, just by the Palace of El Prez, listening to his speech regarding the last elections, which he won with the stunning 96% of votes, of course... his opponent went missing after that, Penultimo gave him a ticket to go to a vacation you know... there's nothing more to that.Beautiful soundtrack! They picked the music perfectly. It's one of the best out there for me personally. What better way to cheer yourself up than with some latino music, dances and songs!!!!!! Yaaaay!-The gameplay: simple, yet a little harder to master! Build buildings, get more people on the island, pray not to run out of money- profit out of it.Thing is, you need a strong economy early on, otherwise you will quickly run out of money. Start building tourist spots and them pesky tourists will just pour and pour money in El Presidente's Swiss Bank Account- that is all he needs to know! Build better housing for your citizens, pay them more when you earn more money, make them happy, win the next elections!Or just leave things as they are, gain a few rebels here and there, issue martial law, screw elections, survive an assassination attempt and keep ruling this beautiful nation that Tropico is! It is up to you! But beware, US ans USSR's ships are always seeking for that one moment to invade your country. El Prez must react fast! Quick, Penultimo, build that nuclear program.All in all, this is a fantastic game if you want to spend some free time gaming and to chill after a rough day! It makes you have fun and be happy.I have spent hundreds of hours on it on a non-steam version, and, believe me, every time i come back, I find something new. And this is what I cherish in Tropico!I strongly recommend this game to everyone

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Tropico 4 is a great, in-depth look at how to manage and run a city and its economy. It differs to that of SimCity and Anno as the economy and the needs of the citizens are of great importance to succeeding; imagine running a Sim household translated to city scenario, with the different aspects of society affecting citizen happiness. It's very humourous and can be considered a great introuction to the city building/simulation genre. With the addition of the multiple factions in the game, including the rebels and foregin powers, you further have to micro-manage your expenses and make sure the right people are pleased. The game did teach me about the numerous factions which can be approriated to real life such as nationalists, commuinists, capitalists, loyalists etc, which adds, for lack of a better term, political realism to the game. You really get a hands on feel to what commodities are being produced, where you are generating money, and where you are losing it, with the aid of an Almanac displaying the numerical statatics of your city for easy referral. You dont feel seperated or alienated during the city building process as you are constantly being advised by the numerous, quirky characters, especially your loyally passionate, animated PA, and you do feel like your actions are being counted on which adds an additional layer of immersion. The soundtrack is EXCELLENT, albeit short (which therefore means you can hear you favourite track again shortly :D), with catchy jives and upbeat tempos as the tropican culture is captured perfectly and you do really feel like El Presidente amongst all the exotic instrumentation. The tutorial could have been further in-depth with explaining certain features as I had to resort to googling some aspects, but overall the campaign is great and it feels very rewarding when your exports return an enromous profit bringing you out of debt :P. The way in which the campaign is structured with individual missions means you can schedule and pace your gaming time, instead of wondering when the end is in sight. The different avenues of money-making, i.e. the numerous exporting commodities, means you can differ your stragety each time you play a mission, without routine-like, repeting methods. With the specific, analytical nature of the gameplay, you aren't looking at expansive, sprawling cities and skylines, so this game does create an attractive niche in the genre without detracting purpose to playing other mainstream city building games. I havent played the dlc campaigns yet, but in addition to that you get more outfit options for your avatar and decorations,  I wouldn't count them as must-have additions, the campaign dlc would probably be sufficient. I'm really keen to check out Tropico 5 now and see how it differs and what new features are implemented. Grabbing Tropico 4 (presumably the Steam Special Edition) for under $10 is well worth it, no buyers remorse. Overall, I rate this game 4 out of 5 spainards.(Forgive the long review, it's 4:30am and I'm carelessly indulging in my BA knowlege, I need sleep.)

If you are on the fence about this game I would say definetely give it a try. If you enjoy games like Simcity or Banished it felt like a mix of the two with extra polital elements tacked on.

er 26, 2013
												After EA screwed up SimCity 5 (I don't care what the correct name is), I like many others have turned to find another quirky city-building game. For the game, the learning curve is slightly steep. The UI is counterintuitive to full micro-management and a lot of in-game information are guesstimates. After 3 hours, you will find yourself immersed in the corny South American voice acting, blatant political tomfoolery and plain craziness. After 5 hours, you will find ways to exploit your low educated workers by forcing them toil on corn fields for a $5 wage. After 7 hours, you will destroy pristine islands for the sake of crude oil deposits. Then you realise you've put in 20+ hours. And then you will write a review.

												Overall 7/10.Definitely the best "City building" simulator out there.Pros:- Between missions, goals, and mutlitasking, there's plenty to do.- Some of the cities/ i slands you come up with are a beauty.- There's a strong sense of humor, borderline parody, that is not overdone, but does make you smile here and there.- You are free to do whatever you want, really and do not have to follow a path or a "if you don't do this you can't win" playing strategy.Cons:- As most city building games, it is rather pointless :)- There's no option to "play forever" and actually do all what what you would like that (some of the user created scenarios help, though)- After a while, the jokes get old.- DRM yuck.- Too many tiny DLCS, some good, some irrelevant.So, it meets the expectactions, it's fun to play, and you won't regret it if you got it on a sale.

												A very interesting take on a country building / management game where strategy is the key. The array of buildings is quite impressive and the city decor is in ample supply with everything you need to make your mark on your carribean island. You can be a democratic leader giving your citizens all their rights, or become a tyrant and run a submissive country. BEWRAE TYRANTS!! You will make enemies in the form of rebels :) So Bon appetite. This game has decent game mechanics and has quite a in depth feel to it with a strong submerssive experience. You get to get involved in the politics, running of industry's, a commander, and an economic guru whilst all the while keeping relations happy with the U.S.A, U.S.S.R, China, Europe and the Middle East. When I bought it, I bought it on a whim and for a bargain price to at the time and now after many hours I can say its been very much worth it and I still haven't completed it or got bored with it. It could do with some glitches and bugs that could be fixed but they aren't that frequent I have found when playing. Also the game mechanics could be tweaked a little more and have even more building options. Thats just me being picky and my personal preference. I highly rate and recommend this game to anyone who is into this kind of genre. I will continue to keep playing it for many more hours. Nice work Kalypso :)

r 5, 2014
												At first glance it's a simulation city game. And it is. But when you actually play it. It is far more than that. You are afterall a dictator in this game trying to either satisfy your citizen or your own future self (retired old man). To achieve that you can choose your way of ruling, go all in with the old fashioned way (the military way) or go all peace loving dictator.The first couple of hours was a learning course kinda bored me but then when i played on sandbox mode, a friend sent me a text asking how fun this game is. That was when it hit me, i could'nt believe myself sitting for 5 hours straight trying to satisfy all the NPC and Factions!

content:
ber 13, 2016
Product received for free
												E' il primo tropico che provo e il gioco, se piace il genere, ti regala diverse soddisfazioni. Non l'ho preso prima perchè non lo conoscevo e grazie ad un sito l'ho preso gratis. Tropico 4 si presenta ben strutturato e con vari tipi di gioco possibili rendendo la longevità strettamente collegata all'immaginazione del giocatore. In che senso? Nel senso che, oltre ad offrire un bel po' di isole dove costruire la tua cittadina, ti offre anche numerosi metodi per fare crescere la tua isola sotto il punto di vista demografico ed economico. Possiamo benissimo paragonarlo alla realtà; Vogliamo puntare sul turismo? Bene valorizziamo il territorio, vogliamo puntare sullo sfruttamento della mano d'opera stile multinazionale sanguisughe? Bene potete. Quindi la durata e soprattutto il gusto di giocarci varia da giocatore a giocatore ed in base a come decide di comportarsi, è ovvio che un giocatore molto metodico che punta sempre sugli stessi fattori si annoierà prima rispetto ad un altro che preferisce uno stile di gioco più vario e ricco di sorprese. La grafica è senza infamia e senza lode, ma per gli appassionati del genere si sa, non è cosi rilevante come lo sarebbe in un fps perchè le priorità sono, ovviamente, altre.Consigliato!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2013
												Personally, I LOVE this game! It's pretty challenging on first playing, however the controls arent that difficult and tactics come naturally. I would only really recommend this to people who have played other games like it in the past and enjoyed them (Example: Sim City) If you've never played a game of this genre I wouldn't recommend this as a starting point, I'd probably recommend Sim City.Character customisation could use a little work, what with the head graphics clipping through hats, hair, accesories. Although, its pretty nice to have the option of not going with the pre-sets. The amount of detailed graphics that have been added, especially where structures are concerned makes this a very beautiful even on low graphical settings. The general public in this game all have their own "personalities" made up of individual thoughts and needs, some needing more of one thing than others. Another nice feature that sits hand in hand with this is that if they do anything wrong, there are five actions you can take against them, avalible at your discretionAdditionally its nice that your character is actually present on the map, and are usable however its also nice that you dont HAVE to use them, they will get on with there own stuff while you concentate on maintaining the town.Lastly sandbox mode is hugely customisable and although on first glance the settings avaliable dont seem like they'll change much, I've played many games on sandbox that have all been vastly different and not just because of my tactics and style.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
12, 2014
												Tropico lets you be the dictator of your own Tropical Island. As 'el Presidente' of Tropico your will is law. Like in other city-building games you get to choose what to build, what demands shall be met, but also how to deal with unrest. The main differences with a game like Anno are that: 1) Tropico plays a bit more casual when it comes to usage of space, but does let you create roads more freely and 2) you have to deal with your population, 3) you have to deal with the international super-powers to prevent being invaded. Unique in it's setting combined with a unique sense of humour (that extends to their facebook page, example: "El Presidente takes his hat off for Kim Jong Un! Congrats to such a neatly organized and executed election. At the moment he's thinking about sending over Penultimo for a little worshop"), I can totally recomend this game. Tropico 4 looks exactly like the third installment and if you buy the game without the expansion "Modern Times" there is really no difference. The Tropico 4 in a pack is actually quite worth your money if you enjoy city-building games and or government games. One MAYOR negative point for this game: it comes with terribly annoying DRM. The game is completely singleplayer, there is no multiplayer element whatsoever. You buy the game here on steam, but you still need a seperate account with Kalypso. You need to log-on to Kalypso everytime you boot the game. There is no reason for this. But I'm sticking with the positive review, because I also hope they drop the DRM someday (please email them about it like I did).When it comes to maturity of this game, when it comes to violence, repression and persecution this game tops them all. The choices you make lead to rebellions. Members of society decide to leave the city and hide in the woods on the island, pick up an AK and fight you. You need an army to quell them, and this gives some action, some firefights in the game (no strategy element) and 'el Presidente' (your customizable ingame avatar, you can even build a golden statue of your avatar!) will also join these fights.Your will is law. If you do't like religion, dont build any churches and be prepared for angry people demanding a church. You can even 'oust' an entire faction from the island, taking away that faction's voice in sociey (be prepared for rebellions). And if you really hate religion, you can also build labor camps a jails to 're-educate' them or even let the army kill the members of that faction. Same goes for criminals, imprison them, kill them, let them be, your choice. You can just pull out a list, arange it as you see fit and choose your actions on the individuals on that list. And every gamer has a sadistic mind, even if it's hidden away somewhere... and in this game, you can zoom in to streetview level, follow around the individuals whose fate has been chosen and see it take place.When you first play the game it's quite hard. But once you get the hang of it, it becomes too easy really. It's a great game, but it does have even more potential.If you had never heard about this game before, like me before Tropico 3, but are interested... try it out. Tropico 5 is coming out in 2014, so there might be a nice sale for part 4 coming!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2012
												This game is really great and you should buy it.First, the cons: - There's a bit of a curve in figuring out exactly what the people think is reasonable (for example, protip: housing prices should be 1/3 of the person's salary, rounded down, and entertainment should be exactly their salary). - The missions are very scripted and the gameplay very freeform, resulting in occasional basically-guaranteed losses or complete non-challenges after you complete an objective and the next impossible-to-predict-the-first-time-trying scripted event occurs. - Being a tyrant is really underpowered vs. being totally nice and helpful.Besides that, this game is packed with wit, charm, and fun. Tropico 3 was just a remake of Tropico 1, but this game really takes strides in perfecting the forumula. Any good sim-builder needs lots of knobs and buttons to fiddle with, and this game has a bunch of them - and best of all, they're generally not packed painfully into drab numerical menus. There are no up and down buttons for employment; you actually click a socket for a worker's face to close it off and limit how many people the building will employ. This and *actually helpful* tooltips (some devs get it wrong, somehow) make the game immediately accessible. You'll have your work cut out for you balancing the desires of the various factions, and who you decide to please and who you decide to push to the brink of rebellion will often depend entirely on the resources of the island and your mission objectives. A huge problem with most games of this genre is the tendency for a single strategy to win every time; while this is still present in Tropico 4 to some degree, the missions are crafted carefully enough, with enough special conditions to disrupt your winning strategies, that it's less of a problem here than in any other game I've ever played in this genre.The writing in the game is top-notch and if you don't find yourself smirking from time to time at the bald-faced satire, then you need to get your sense of humor checked out. This game finds creative ways to poke fun at cold-war banana republics, stereotypes, popular video games, and more. At no point do you feel guilty for being a big, stupid tyrant, because all the international powers are bigger, stupider, and more tyrannical. This gives a fun sense of empathy to El Presidente despite his self-serving nature, and motivates you to shelter the helpless people of Tropico from the uncaring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on both sides of the iron curtain... and maybe launder some tax money as payment while you're doing them the service.I can't recommend this game highly enough. I've bought all the DLC and earned every achievement because I can't get enough of El Presidente. If you're actually considering this game enough to be here reading reviews about it, do yourself a favor and go for it.

content:
er 17, 2013
												8.5/10Tropico 4 is a sim game where you control an island in the carribean. As the supreme ruler, you have power over everything. But don't take this to mean you can do whatever you want. You have to manage relations with the various factions on the island. If you treat them badly, they will make your life difficult. Some may even join the rebels and contend militarily for power. You must do this while keeping funds up and trying to pad your offshore bank account as much as possible.The game has a robust campaign that's relatively fun to play through. Sandbox is ok, I mainly use it for fooling around and trying self-imposed goals. There are a massive amount of user created challenges. Those are where the true fun comes in. But these things can become boring after time.It has some DLC. The best bang for your buck would come from Modern Times. Modern Times adds a ton of buildings and edicts. It also has it's own campaigns. The other DLCs are ok, but they don't really warrant the $5 price point. They add traits for your president, a special building, a mission, and some vanity items. Get them on sale.In all, I would reccommend this for anyone who enjoys sim games and some that don't. It is much easier to get into than some of the others (I'm looking at you Cities XL)Edit: The soundtrack is also fabulous. Very nice island themed music

y 8, 2013
												Personally, I LOVE this game! It's pretty challenging on first playing, however the controls arent that difficult and tactics come naturally. I would only really recommend this to people who have played other games like it in the past and enjoyed them (Example: Sim City) If you've never played a game of this genre I wouldn't recommend this as a starting point, I'd probably recommend Sim City.Character customisation could use a little work, what with the head graphics clipping through hats, hair, accesories. Although, its pretty nice to have the option of not going with the pre-sets. The amount of detailed graphics that have been added, especially where structures are concerned makes this a very beautiful even on low graphical settings. The general public in this game all have their own "personalities" made up of individual thoughts and needs, some needing more of one thing than others. Another nice feature that sits hand in hand with this is that if they do anything wrong, there are five actions you can take against them, avalible at your discretionAdditionally its nice that your character is actually present on the map, and are usable however its also nice that you dont HAVE to use them, they will get on with there own stuff while you concentate on maintaining the town.Lastly sandbox mode is hugely customisable and although on first glance the settings avaliable dont seem like they'll change much, I've played many games on sandbox that have all been vastly different and not just because of my tactics and style.

content:
y 22, 2015
												Welcome to the fourth installment of the popular 'Tropico' franchise. Highly acclaimed with a ton of rave reviews, but is this game as good as people say? Yes. Yes it is.If you are new to the Tropico franchise like I was, then here is a very quick rundown of the game:You are El Presidente, the leader of a small Carribean 'paradise' called Tropico. Your main aim is to transform Tropico, an underdeveloped and practically lifeless bunch of Islands, into a world superpower by any and all means necessary. You will  straight up notice some very funny parallels to the real world as Tropico is basically Cuba, and El Presidente is based off a number of socialist and communist figures such as Fidel Castro and Che Guevera. Throughout the campaigns in the game you will have total control over Tropico which will see you lead your state onto the international platform for either good, or bad reasons. You will need to balance your popularity with your people by pleasing the various factions present within your society; something that is easier said than done. Similarly, you need to stay on the right side of the world superpowers as the game is based during the Cold War and your decisions will vary your popularity with the United States of America (US), or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). There are other world leaders but they don't threaten to invade you, well, as far as i'm aware anyway. Alongside all of this, you must work to transform Tropico by investing money into things like housing, welfare, food and resources, government, tourism, etc. Make sure you don't blow your budget too badly though because the world superpowers don't like broke countries. Also, prepare for major natural disasters that will kill your people, ruin your buildings and crops.Some people may read this and say 'This is just a mix of the Sims/Cities mixed with Democracy or something like that'. In a way maybe it is, but here is why I think Tropico is way better. Political corruption is encouraged in the game. Need to get more products out? Run a sweatshop. Rebels annoying you? Wire tap houses, impose martial law, conscript citizens into your army against their will. Getting too many immigrants and have shacks overunning your beautiful paradise? Force emigration. Faction leader or protesters becoming too popular? Have them eliminated or arrested for herecy. Minister of Foreign Affairs made a bad decision? Fire him and arrest him. . . See what I mean? How does this not sound fun?If you like being the corrupt leader of Cuba and focusing more on being famous than the wellbeing of your citizens who you can force to never leave a state with poor housing, bad health conditions, slave labour, conscription, propeganda, rebels, frequent natural disasters, and 'accidents' or disappearences happening way too reguarly.. than this is the game for you.Buy it. Play it. Live it.TROPICO 4.

content:
, 2014
												Tropico 4 is a great, in-depth look at how to manage and run a city and its economy. It differs to that of SimCity and Anno as the economy and the needs of the citizens are of great importance to succeeding; imagine running a Sim household translated to city scenario, with the different aspects of society affecting citizen happiness. It's very humourous and can be considered a great introuction to the city building/simulation genre. With the addition of the multiple factions in the game, including the rebels and foregin powers, you further have to micro-manage your expenses and make sure the right people are pleased. The game did teach me about the numerous factions which can be approriated to real life such as nationalists, commuinists, capitalists, loyalists etc, which adds, for lack of a better term, political realism to the game. You really get a hands on feel to what commodities are being produced, where you are generating money, and where you are losing it, with the aid of an Almanac displaying the numerical statatics of your city for easy referral. You dont feel seperated or alienated during the city building process as you are constantly being advised by the numerous, quirky characters, especially your loyally passionate, animated PA, and you do feel like your actions are being counted on which adds an additional layer of immersion. The soundtrack is EXCELLENT, albeit short (which therefore means you can hear you favourite track again shortly :D), with catchy jives and upbeat tempos as the tropican culture is captured perfectly and you do really feel like El Presidente amongst all the exotic instrumentation. The tutorial could have been further in-depth with explaining certain features as I had to resort to googling some aspects, but overall the campaign is great and it feels very rewarding when your exports return an enromous profit bringing you out of debt :P. The way in which the campaign is structured with individual missions means you can schedule and pace your gaming time, instead of wondering when the end is in sight. The different avenues of money-making, i.e. the numerous exporting commodities, means you can differ your stragety each time you play a mission, without routine-like, repeting methods. With the specific, analytical nature of the gameplay, you aren't looking at expansive, sprawling cities and skylines, so this game does create an attractive niche in the genre without detracting purpose to playing other mainstream city building games. I havent played the dlc campaigns yet, but in addition to that you get more outfit options for your avatar and decorations,  I wouldn't count them as must-have additions, the campaign dlc would probably be sufficient. I'm really keen to check out Tropico 5 now and see how it differs and what new features are implemented. Grabbing Tropico 4 (presumably the Steam Special Edition) for under $10 is well worth it, no buyers remorse. Overall, I rate this game 4 out of 5 spainards.(Forgive the long review, it's 4:30am and I'm carelessly indulging in my BA knowlege, I need sleep.)

content:
19, 2014
												This game had intrigued me with its ads but I wasn't sure if it was worth a buy. Finally I got a good sale on it and was stoked to give it a shot. Sure enough this game is fantastic. Definetely has the same feel as other city building games but with some layers of complexity that feel really nice. Instead of putting you in a world that doesn't really make sense or is obviously fictional they give you something that could actually be plausible. I never knew I would enjoy playing the part of a island dictator but sure enough it's an original enough idea that I have been hooked for hours now. If you are on the fence about this game I would say definetely give it a try. If you enjoy games like Simcity or Banished it felt like a mix of the two with extra polital elements tacked on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 22, 2015
												Welcome to the fourth installment of the popular 'Tropico' franchise. Highly acclaimed with a ton of rave reviews, but is this game as good as people say? Yes. Yes it is.If you are new to the Tropico franchise like I was, then here is a very quick rundown of the game:You are El Presidente, the leader of a small Carribean 'paradise' called Tropico. Your main aim is to transform Tropico, an underdeveloped and practically lifeless bunch of Islands, into a world superpower by any and all means necessary. You will  straight up notice some very funny parallels to the real world as Tropico is basically Cuba, and El Presidente is based off a number of socialist and communist figures such as Fidel Castro and Che Guevera. Throughout the campaigns in the game you will have total control over Tropico which will see you lead your state onto the international platform for either good, or bad reasons. You will need to balance your popularity with your people by pleasing the various factions present within your society; something that is easier said than done. Similarly, you need to stay on the right side of the world superpowers as the game is based during the Cold War and your decisions will vary your popularity with the United States of America (US), or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). There are other world leaders but they don't threaten to invade you, well, as far as i'm aware anyway. Alongside all of this, you must work to transform Tropico by investing money into things like housing, welfare, food and resources, government, tourism, etc. Make sure you don't blow your budget too badly though because the world superpowers don't like broke countries. Also, prepare for major natural disasters that will kill your people, ruin your buildings and crops.Some people may read this and say 'This is just a mix of the Sims/Cities mixed with Democracy or something like that'. In a way maybe it is, but here is why I think Tropico is way better. Political corruption is encouraged in the game. Need to get more products out? Run a sweatshop. Rebels annoying you? Wire tap houses, impose martial law, conscript citizens into your army against their will. Getting too many immigrants and have shacks overunning your beautiful paradise? Force emigration. Faction leader or protesters becoming too popular? Have them eliminated or arrested for herecy. Minister of Foreign Affairs made a bad decision? Fire him and arrest him. . . See what I mean? How does this not sound fun?If you like being the corrupt leader of Cuba and focusing more on being famous than the wellbeing of your citizens who you can force to never leave a state with poor housing, bad health conditions, slave labour, conscription, propeganda, rebels, frequent natural disasters, and 'accidents' or disappearences happening way too reguarly.. than this is the game for you.Buy it. Play it. Live it.TROPICO 4.

content:
ber 8, 2016
												Almost got 100 hours into the game. I absolutely love the fact that I haven't beaten a single sandbox game yet. My guess is I'm just not presidential material. There are dozens of variables you proabbly should to keep in mind while playing; exporting&importing prices, pay rates, city layout, rebellion. The game has options you can set before starting your game, in sandbox mode, options such as; political stability, extreme weather occurences, customization for the president's looks, heritage, how he got his power, his traits. It may look like it is a children game on the outside, but this baby has potential to be a time waster for anybody who picks it up!9/10. You can become a dictator over your people. The US, Russia AND the rebels could want you dead. But your palace guards & dozens of army bases & guard posts should keep you a safe distance away from the action. Only one way to find out...Also, I got like 5 DLC's for free for some reason. I checked my purchase history and they weren't in there so I assume everybody got them, but if not THANKS.

content:
er 30, 2011
												To me, Tropico 4 has always been more dear than Tropico 3, even though I played Tropico 3 first with the fact that Tropico 4 could be named as Tropico 3.5 to tell the truth. However, what gives Tropico 4 an edge over 3, are following reasons: Better feedback. I remember playing 3 and sometimes getting confused where I'm going wrong. 4 fixes that very well. Campaign. It's funny, it's lengthy and overall well done. DLC. Or more like "Modern Times". It's pretty much the main reason how Tropico 4 stands on it's own legs rather than feeling rewarmed 3. Other DLCs are... eh. Unnecessary. Quests inside of game. They repeat themselves in the end but gives little bit more dynamic in game and goals to keep things interesting. Small improved things you'll see there and there.I still recommend getting 4 over 3, especially if you're new to series and even if you don't own 4 yet but you own 3, there's no reason to get 4 from the sales.It's a game which 3 should've truly been.

												I give Tropica 4 two thumbs up. This is my first Tropica game and I find it very appealing. It is pretty f-ing awesome. I literally just played Tropico 4 for 10 hours straight. This game is one of the best city builder games I have ever had the pleasure to binge play. The controls are super easy to understand, even my grandmother could figure them out. The graphics are pretty good, better than most game I have played on my pc but nothing to write home about. One of the best things in life is laughter and Tropica 4 keeps me laughing while I play and build my beautiful island. Your little helpers if you choose to have them on are funny looking characters that make me laugh just looking at them but thewy are also really helpful. Everything is set up so you can place everything  with ease and lightning speed. Overall Tropica 4 is a great buy and you will certainly get hours and hours of game playing, island building, throwing people in jail for no reason kind of fun out of it.

ber 8, 2016
												Almost got 100 hours into the game. I absolutely love the fact that I haven't beaten a single sandbox game yet. My guess is I'm just not presidential material. There are dozens of variables you proabbly should to keep in mind while playing; exporting&importing prices, pay rates, city layout, rebellion. The game has options you can set before starting your game, in sandbox mode, options such as; political stability, extreme weather occurences, customization for the president's looks, heritage, how he got his power, his traits. It may look like it is a children game on the outside, but this baby has potential to be a time waster for anybody who picks it up!9/10. You can become a dictator over your people. The US, Russia AND the rebels could want you dead. But your palace guards & dozens of army bases & guard posts should keep you a safe distance away from the action. Only one way to find out...Also, I got like 5 DLC's for free for some reason. I checked my purchase history and they weren't in there so I assume everybody got them, but if not THANKS.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Bursting at the seams with charming, satirical humour and a kickass caribbean/hispanic soundtrack, Tropico 4puts the players in the shoes of El Presidente, newly appointed leader of the island nation of Tropico. As el Presidente, the player can choose to govern the island in whatever manner as he/she pleases.The game mostly plays out as a kind of city sim, but with more/less complexity in some departments. On the political side of things, as El Presidente, you are in charge of the government's local and foreign policies, appointing ministers and even building your own army/glorified bodyguard force. However, the city-building aspects of zoning districts, managing utilities and directing traffic are vastly simplified. Ultimately, the game is an island economy simulator, with everything else existing to supplement it.Whilst the possibilities to play Tropico 4 however you want to play it is endless, the only two playstyles that will bring you any sort of success is to become a relentless industrial capitalist or relentless tourism-focused capitalist. Combine that with the game's huge focus on economy and moneymaking, and the campaign starts feeling repetitive.Hold on though! That is where the game's humour holds up it's otherwise weak campaign. Putting aside the campaign's nonsensical and overly convoluted plot, the characters have large personalities that brilliantly lampoon world leaders and common stereotypes. The characters give Tropico 4 a vibrant personality that is the shining pillar that holds it up above the multitude of other bland, boring city sims/ economy simulators.Like the islands in the game itself, one cannot be too fooled with the outwards image that Tropico 4 projects and ignore the less pretty, less polished inner workings. The interface, while elegantly simple, poorly presents vital data and is far too simple for the task of managing an island. Micromanagement is non-existent. Once your island reaches a critical mass of population, traffic inevitably slows down, frustrating all your plans.While I had fun with Tropico 4, it's many flaws stemming from the repetitive nature of it's fundamental gameplay mechanics holds it back from being a true representation of Caribbean island governance. However, the game's exuberant and charming humour serves to alleviate the lack in gameplay variety and somewhat dated graphics.I mean, who doesn't love El Presidente?  (love El Presidente or else)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ARBITRARY NUMBER RATING : 7.4/10~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

												I had always been curious to try this series and I'm glad that I eventually did. I started off with its third instalment and that got me hooked. This game improves upon an already good formula with its superior graphics, campaign and detail. For those of you who are unfamiliar with the series, think Caribbean city-builder. One of the most appealing things about this game is just its all-round humour. While being a tad childish, you can still get a laugh out of some of the jokes - especially the stereotypes. The game's awesome latin soundtrack is also pretty good too. It's a very self-aware game and that's why I love it. If you've never played a game in the series before, this is where you should start.

content:
er 25, 2013
												I bought this game on an extreme sale not really expecting much other than some cheap entertainment, and I ended up being pleasantly surprised.The player take the role of a South American dictator who undergoes various trials to develop the island nation of Tropico.  You can choose to embrace US-style captialism, Soviet-style communism, or a tourism-based economy.  Your island is home to various competing interests that you must work to satisfy, so there's a lot of things to juggle.  The main campaign is challenging and diverse, I chose to play through that instead of just building stand-alone islands.One of the most unexpected positives of the game is that the campaign is just plain funny.  The banter between your dictator avatar, your advisors, the various diplomats you engage with, and the other NPCs is consistently entertaining, and is a well-written parody of Cold War era foreign relations with Latin America.My wife and I played the game side-by-side and enjoyed bantering about the various levels and the decisions that we made.

content:
er 7, 2013
												The most basic question from a lot of people when they look into Tropico 4 is this: Is it any better than Tropico 3?Short answer, In some ways yes and in other many sad ways nope. The Tropico series for those who haven't played any Tropico games at all is this. You are a Tin Pot Dictator of a small cluster of fictional Islands in the Carribean. You aim is to get rich stuffing as much money as you can into your off shore Swiss Bank Account and try and not get overthrow by the angry factions you have to appease, the people and finally the angry Cold War era Super Powers. Sounds simple right?But anyways, Tropico 4 versus 3. The general improvements between the two games don't seem massive to be brutally honest. Some of the problems from 3 are still there (triggering Edicts still has no visual effects apart from your bank balance, same graphics and the same damn music) but 4 brings some improvements to the table. It is clear they learnt something from the DLC and Expansion of Tropico 3 as quite a few features have been ported over to the newer game. I'm sure there is  a huge amount of under the hook tweaks and additions that make it a slightly smoother experince from Tropico 3.For one Tropico 4 has a bit more soul and is a lot more amusing. Instead of that single irritating Radio DJ with the same 6 voice clips El Presidente‎ pretty much shares his palace with his aides and faction heads who bring a new feature to the Tropico table with missions that appease your government, the factions or just a slightly easier way to help fill your bank balance or satisfy your people to some extent. And it isn't just your guys the faceless super powers from the first game have been given faces AND both the EU, China and the Middle East have joined in to squabble for your tiny Islands precious resources. This is a pretty good thing as it also gives you a reason to actually play the Main Campaign that has been tweaked a lot around these new additions. They also make sandbox games a slightly less tedious treck.There is of course the mandatory couple of new buildings of every type and a couple of new outfits to dress up your Corrupt Carribean Dictator too. And yeah sadly that is it. Of course there is also the suspicious hefty amount of DLC packs with a lot of additional content that should really have been in the game. This game really is more Tropico: The Directors Cut The Electric Phantom Part II than Tropico 4. But hey, they added Twitter with the Facebook Social functions and new achivements if that is your thing!I sort of wish they made the effort and a DLC that added some new Islands or Music as around the 20 hour mark like with a decent old movie you love to break out every few months to comfort yourself you eventually notice the limited flaws.So yeah, final word. Pick it up with all the DLC during a sale if you are a big Tropico/Management game fan or want to try something new.

												Build your tropical island paradise, or build a fascist dictatorship of tyrrany and oppression. In Tropico 4, you are the dictator of a small Caribbean island. Grow your nation, become an economical powerhouse, a military powerhouse, or a vacation paradise. One major upside to this game is that it has a lot more decoration buildings and items and isn't as strict about buildings needing to be placed near a road, like Tropico 5. So grab your guns and fight for tyranny and oppression, or against it!Viva Tropico! Viva El Presidente!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 2, 2014
												As someone who adores Tropico 3, I felt skeptical about playing this game, since most of the assets are ripped straight from its predescessor, and the mechanics are very similar, although distinctly improved.What I discovered when I finally got around to playing it, however, is a beautifully silly game. Where Tropico 3 had tossed out puns and occasional tongue-in-cheek exclamations over the radio, Tropico 4 has mostly-voiced campaigns, a suite of comedic characters with hilarious interactions, a genuinely funny radio announcement for a lot of the buildings (which does not play as frustratingly frequently as in 3), and a distinct sense of absurdity in the very structure of the campaign. For instance, one of the campaign missions has a series of voice clips which are direct spoofs of "the most interesting man in the world," which left me giggling to myself.

content:
er 31, 2015
												This game as a city builder and government simulation game is a perfect mixture of genres. You build and industrialize a small island in the Caribbean during the cold war times throughout the game the USSR and USA are constantly fighting for your favor a perfect example of the small conflicts of the cold war that don't get too much attention. The characters that appear to you in the game are all very well done caricatures of their home nation or political alignment and are good for a quick laugh when they bring up the issues of the island to you. The game is complex enough for a veteran of these type of games to enjoy it and simple enough for newcomers to have fun too. You can choose from many ways to rule your country, a democracy, a dictatorship, nationalist, communist. the diversity makes this game feel to have no limits and infinite possibilities. I give this game a 9/10 if you want to get into city builder games or civilization type games this is a good stepping stone.

content:
r 18, 2014
												Really fun city builder. If you miss games like Simcity from the past this is a great modern take on it. By modern I mean up to date graphics and gameplay mechanics, as the time period this takes place during the cold war 60s-80s era in the Carribean. The campaign does an awesome job balancing things out to teach you all the mechanics and demonstrate how to build a thriving city. If only the politicians of today understood such basic concepts.You also get the option to just endlessly develop a single city which is suprising entertaining even after spending a ton of time doing the same things. There's always one more thing to develop, or one more issue needing attention.  There's a newer version of the game out now, but this one is still a great game I highly recommend.

content:
3, 2015
												Two words...Guilty. Pleasure. Buy this and stick it in reserve for a rainy day- it will get you through. Honestly you will never be so satisfied sitting about doing nothing with your life.You are thrust into the role of El Presidente <choose your name>, President of Tropico- a group of third world, scum ridden islands prone to violence, crime and communism. Your job? Up to you, as long as you're making money.... Build up the economy, provide your citizens with food and homes, get them on side (legally or otherwise), get them to work mining resources, sell those resources to the world, build relationships with super powers, build an army to fight rebels off while you manipulate the masses, build touristy crap on your island and rob the foreign mob, then stick as much cash into your own swiss account as you can- and try not to kill too many people on the way. Oh, and just for giggles, build loads of statues of yourself.

content:
, 2014
												Quick Review - Tropico 4 is the best entry in the Tropico franchise so far. If you are not fimiliar with Tropico, here's s short rundown:> You are El Presidente> You are the newest ruler of Tropico Islands> Build ♥♥♥♥.> Juggle your nation's relationship with the Capatilist United States and the Communist USSR.> $$$With a great map editor that can be used to share your creations with the world, and about 100 hours of content and endless replayability, this game is 100% worth the current $20 asking price. If you ever wanted to play Sim City on a tropical island and get to chose wether to be a ♥♥♥♥-bag control freak or a man of the people, try this game for sure.There is plenty of game modes. Like I mentioned before, there's a map editor where you can change the entire layout of of pre-made island. You can raise mountains to the exact pixel you wish, create rivers of gold deposits to fill your wallet with cash, and best of all, add any kind of settings you want. The island is your canvas. You can be as artistic as you want. Want a forest here? Go for it. Feel like ruling an island full of nothing volcanic ash and a few ancient ruins? Your funeral. Do as you please, you are El Presidente!The commentary of your island's growth (or demise, if you are THAT guy) is done by Penultimo, your most trustworthy advisor (and your only advisor) and Sunny Smiles, a hippie with a really bad dental problem... perhaps they should have added "dentist office" as a building option. It is witty, creative, and sometimes downright made my laugh. The humour in this game is very much to my liking. Every joke is either a really good one, or one that is so cheesy it still makes you smile. The person who represents the United States introduces himself as such: " Good day, El Presidente. I am Senetor Nick Richards. I am not a crook!"On the negative side, the music - while good - gets repetitive after a while. You hear the same 5 songs over and over. I actually had to look for a mod to add more tracks in it, just to be disappointed there is none as of yet. At least the songs are really catchy and upbeat, otherwise this would practically ruin the experience.The only other problem I have with the game is the lack of ways to appeal to the enviromentalist and militarist factions. The damn hippies whine everytime you cut down a few trees... even when it is to build a wind turbine. They just seem to hate everything you do, especially if it makes you money. Open a mine in the middle of a craig? Well screw you, we're not voting for you in the next election. What's that? You built a garbage dump on a distant valley to reduce polution in the streets? Impeche El Presidente for trying to accomidate our desires.Overall, great game. Final Verdict: 9/10 for City Builder fans, 7.5/10 for others.

												Two words...Guilty. Pleasure. Buy this and stick it in reserve for a rainy day- it will get you through. Honestly you will never be so satisfied sitting about doing nothing with your life.You are thrust into the role of El Presidente <choose your name>, President of Tropico- a group of third world, scum ridden islands prone to violence, crime and communism. Your job? Up to you, as long as you're making money.... Build up the economy, provide your citizens with food and homes, get them on side (legally or otherwise), get them to work mining resources, sell those resources to the world, build relationships with super powers, build an army to fight rebels off while you manipulate the masses, build touristy crap on your island and rob the foreign mob, then stick as much cash into your own swiss account as you can- and try not to kill too many people on the way. Oh, and just for giggles, build loads of statues of yourself.

And any uprising that fought against my power would end with severe consequences. I swear to you, I remembered the faces of each one of the rebels and kept note on where they lived and killed them all.TL;DR10/10 IGN

content:
er 31, 2015
												This game as a city builder and government simulation game is a perfect mixture of genres. You build and industrialize a small island in the Caribbean during the cold war times throughout the game the USSR and USA are constantly fighting for your favor a perfect example of the small conflicts of the cold war that don't get too much attention. The characters that appear to you in the game are all very well done caricatures of their home nation or political alignment and are good for a quick laugh when they bring up the issues of the island to you. The game is complex enough for a veteran of these type of games to enjoy it and simple enough for newcomers to have fun too. You can choose from many ways to rule your country, a democracy, a dictatorship, nationalist, communist. the diversity makes this game feel to have no limits and infinite possibilities. I give this game a 9/10 if you want to get into city builder games or civilization type games this is a good stepping stone.

												I felt from the very beginning I played this game this one was good. However other people don't think that way:  ''I don't like it. Its a rubish game''- Said me a friend.I like it but that doesn't mean you will like it. I enjoy it 'cause I play  meanwhile i'm watching a film or speaking with friends by any software or doing whatever. That's because this game is a bit slow. For example, you need X $ to build something. If you don't have that money you won't build it and that's why you must wait and since waiting isn't funny doing another thing wil keep you enjoyed the time you are waiting. Apart from that problem I can't say anything more bad about this gem. ITs a really funny game with lot of action and interesting things. All levels are difficult and you must thing whats the best way to be rich in all of them. So coming again to the question if I'd recommend it: I will to those people who likes doing 2 things at once and to those who like calm games of building a city. And well, i wouldn't pay more than 5€ for this, maybe 10€ if you really want it. If it helped you like it! :P Thanks and have a good day!

...Mama was queen of the mamboPapa was king of the Congodeep down in a jungleI started banging my first bongo...The game is combination of social and economics infrastructure building game (like ... SimCity, Transport Tycoon Deluxe, ...) in communistic/socialistic/imperialistic Carribean island leaded by you.Your role is to become an "famous" el Presidente.In this game you must provide housing, work, food, goods (abroad) for your people which lives on your island. Also there is a lot of "social" buildings like ... school, church, mall, zoo, hotel, restaurant, pub, casino, ... hospital, police, ... farm, power plant, museum, ... and a lot of more.There is also an RPG element ... of your "island leading" ... like pope visit, school reform, better health, ideology, military upgrade, secret police ... and a lot of more.There is also a choise of "mansion" tunning ... for your main building.Sometimes even "rebels" raise up ... and then you must "punish them" or "forgive".There is a lot of new fun features from DLCs ... like smugglers ... modern times (takes tropico from 60's into years 1990-2000)... and a lot of more.+ game type+ a lot of new features (compares to Tropico 3)+ great graphics+ detailed graphics+ "new RPG" elements (school, society, living, religion, housing, education, ... )+ a lot of DLCs+ GREAT SOUNDTRACK (familiar from my Cuba visit ... a lot of Cuban music)- game type- can be more choices of upgrade- same and same things all over and over again - DLCs not FREE !!!- if you have a lot of money ... you dont need to care of anythin (ships will bring food from abroad, you can ship from abroad even workers!)Graphics: 9/10Level detail: 10/10Sounds/Music : 10/10Mechanics: 9/10Idea: 7/10Addicting: 9/10RPG elements: 9/10Story : 9/10----------------------Verdict: 9,5/10 (cant decide between 9/10 or 10/10)

content:
17, 2014
												DO NOT BUY THIS. Don't support bad publisher behavior. Please not that my negative review is not an indictment of the game so much as a warning not to give your money to Kalypso.I was quite looking forward to playing this game, but after waiting an HOUR to be ALLOWED to, I just don't care anymore. Kalypso requires you to register an account with them in order to play this game. Minor annoyance, right? Except that you need to respond to a verification email after registering before it will let you play. I've been waiting for quite some time now, and no email has come. I can't actually PLAY this game I paid money for. I paid for a splash screen, basically. My logged play time is ALL waiting at the registration screen. That's ridiculous, and Kalypso should be embarrassed.Look; I understand that sometimes infrastructure slows things down; you're getting a lot of registrations. Here's the thing: I don't care. That's not my problem. You, Kalypso, decided to impliment a half-♥♥♥♥♥ DRM policy for your game. Therefore the honus is on you to make sure your DRM is as non-obstructive as possible.I really don't even want to play the game at this point. This experience completely soured me on playing the game even if Kalypso does eventually get around to sending me a verification email. I don't want to deal with it anymore. Honestly, Kalypso, this sort of mishandled DRM is what drives people to piracy. Don't worry. I don't pirate games. There are plenty of people who do, though, and I'm willing to bet a cracked copy of your game is MORE functional with LESS hassle than the one I legitimately purchased. That's sad. That's awful. That's a failure on your part, Kalypso, and you have no one to blame but yourself. I will NEVER buy another product from Kalypso Media. I recommend everyone avoid them as well.ADDENDUM: I recieved my registration email at 7:00 a.m. today (August 18th), nearly a full DAY after I bought the game. Because Steam doesn't offer refunds, I'm going to go ahead and try the game out, since I'm out six bucks either way. But my negative review is going to stay here even if the game turns out to be amazing, because people shouldn't have to jump through hoops to assure the publisher that we definitely, DEFINITELY paid for their game; and if there ARE hoops, they should be FUNCTIONAL.

content:
er 31, 2013
												Excellent economics, politics, logistics and overall city building simulation featuring very nicely done funny and overly stereotypical characters.It is true that the basic Tropico 4 is just an improved Tropico 3 which even uses the same engine and mostly the same graphical assets. But the additions are improvements in my oppinion and the things added later with the Modern Times DLC make the game very different from its predecessor. I wouldn't recommend any of the other DLCs unless you buy a whole bundle because the one mission and one building they each provide are barely worth one €uro and most of the added buildings are unbalanced in a way so they just make the game a less difficult.The simulation is very detailed, so you can actually follow every single person on your island on their daily routes through your cities. Finding out about their needs and their thoughts is actually possible. But most of the times I didn't invest too much time into that and focussed on macro-mechanics. Managing to keep your standings on sane levels with both your factions and foreign powers while at the same time doing what is needed to win the mission can be a hard job sometimes.After a long time of playing and optimizing my strategies, the worst thing I found in the game is a point in each round, where the tension is finally removed because the economy is working well, money is flowing in and the people just love you. There was barely ever a game in which there appeared any new difficulty after that point. If you just consider this situation a win it all becomes less of a problem.Another slightly flawed concept seems to be the money in the swiss bank account you can gather through different ways. It makes you have less money available to spend on infrastructure and does not have any other use than improving your game's score. In a future Tropico I hope there is some further use to that. Mechanically sometimes the street building through rocky areas is a bit annoying because you cannot remove the rocks and sometimes need to remove pieces of streets again because there is no angle available anymore to attach a further piece.Also a very unneccessary annoyance is the additional Kalypso account you need to register to access the game. One would think that the need to have a logged in Steam account would be enough to verify that you own the game. I hope for their next game they realize that annoying their legal customers is not a good way to counter piracy.Overall the game gave me more than 120 hours of much appreciated gameplay. I damn well recommend buying this, especially as a complete bundle on sale.

Sounds easy enough, right? I mean, running an island shouldn't be that hard... right?.. right?! Wrong. This game is hard-as-nails, and it doesn't hide it. You're gonna have to learn to manage your money, look after citizens, control riots and well, just make your island the best it can be, no one wants to visit a dead, deserted island. 												I bought Tropico 4 as part of a bundle however despite many attempts and a number of wasted hours have never made it past the 3rd party DRM registration. As a last gasp attempt to get it sorted I have gone directly to their web page and reset two of my email accounts, which were apparentely created by the launcher, even tthough the launcher just whirls away and gives no response. I also created a third email account directly on their web page. However none of this resolved as the emails have never been received (before you ask, I have checked my spam folder).I am pretty tech savvy, working in the industry anyway and have never seen such a poor registration implementation and I include some of the bigger companies in that list as they can often be pretty poor as well. When you are unable to bypass the registration to play a game then you know you are facing an uphill struggle.So in summary I would rate Tropico 4 0/10 as I can't play it and can't bypass the registration (without implementing some hacks, which I refuse to do).The developer response was also pretty poor and never went beyond one question about the issue, which I had already answered in my original post (it would be nice if they actually read it before responding) and one statement to highlight the fact they state the game requires 3rd party DRM registration - I know that, that's why I am posting in their fourms asking for help with the registration!I have read quite a few similar stories in forums, etc.So a big thumbs down from me.

Will never buy games with 3rd party DRA.Edit: Never got the email or any kind of response. Found a workaround to play, still ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I had to.
